top_comment.text:
Sevgili Barkın;
ninja300 ün liste fiyatı 5860 öro. 5860/1,37= 4277 öro KDV li fiyat.
cbr250r nin liste fiyatı 13.500tl. 13.500/2,8 = 4821 öro. 4821/1,08 = 4460 
KDV li fiyat.

demek ki neymiş?
kawasaki 300cc yi hondanın 250cc sinden ucuza veriyormuş? (kalanı nerde mi? 
yazdık ya %37; %8 diye anlarsınız herhalde? )

merak edeceklere kawasakim yok. bir honda bir suzukim var... kawasakide 
çalışan eşim dostum anam babamda yok. ama hesap var kitap var...﻿
top_comment.author: Şehir Gezgini

comments.text:
+ahmet inaç
küstahlığa gerek yok sir sefer kolaya kaçtık diye. hesap yapmayı bilmiyor 
muyum ki " Anlatabildim mi daha açık hesaplayayım mı? " diyorsun hadi 
hesaplayalım...

ninja 300 için 5860/1,18= 4966 öro " motosiklet+ötv " demek ki. ötv bu 
motor için fiyatının %37si olduğuna göre;
                    4966/1,37=3624 öro sadece " çıplak " motosiklet fiyatı 
eder. 

CBR250R için 4821 öro/ 1,18= 4085 öro " motosiklet+ötv " demek ki. ötv bu 
motor için %8 ise;
                     4085/1,08= 3782 öro çıktı sadece " çıplak " 
motorsiklet fiyatı.
şimdi;
               300cc Ninja fiyatı                   250cc CBR fiyatı 
                  3624 öro imiş                       3782 öro imiş
ee ne oldu CBR gene Ninjadan PAHALI çıktı?

bilmem şimdi ben anlatabildim mi?
lafı şimdiki öro kuru muru diye kıvırma hesaplar 15 gün yapıldı...

bilmem ben anlatabildim mi?

comments.text:
+Mert Altınköprü 90 yılından beri motosiklet kullanan 40 yaşında bir 
binici olarak ( detay bilgilerimi verebilirim öneri istersen), şunu 
söyleyebilirim kardeşim, başlangıç motoru dediğin şey başlayacak kişinin 
yeteneğine, ne kadar otomobil ve bisiklet kullanmış olduğuna ve biraz da 
fiziğine ve trafikle ilgili konsantrasyon vs. gibi hususlara bağlı olarak 
kişiye göre değişebilir, evet genelde 10dan 40 beygire kadar, 100 cc.den 
350 cc.ye kadar (ben 350 cc. 27 beygirle başlamıştım zamanında) olan 
aralıktaki motosikletler genel kural olarak uygundur, ki çok yetenekli 
olup, cbr 600f ile başlayan ve hiç bir sorun yaşamayan (ama ayrıca iri-yarı 
ve epey trafik deneyimi olan kişilerdi; ki istisnalar kaideyi 
bozmaz) arkadaşlarım da oldu, 100cc. ile başa çıkamayanlar da oldu. Önemli 
olan kişinin kendine uyanı bulması, yanında da aklı başında bir yol 
göstereni olması (tabi ki genelde 125/250 cc. civarları optimaldir) ve her 
zaman dikkattir.

captions.text:
In 2013, Kawasaki brought out the Ninja 300cc
to replace the very successful Ninja 250.

We gave it some throttle,
let's see what we learned.

Let's start with the looks, you know
it's all about looks, looks, looks,
but this time there's something different.
Do you remember your first girlfriend?

You know, the first time
you held a girl's hand,

you had butterflies in your stomach,
and felt dizzy from the excitement
and you felt, like, "aaaaaaaah"?

But then your next girlfriend
isn't as exciting.

But that first girlfriend, when you
date for the first time you go crazy.

This Ninja 300 has been designed to be
like that first girlfriend for many.

It's designed to make you go crazy,
to mesmerize you,
to make you say "oooooooooh!" etc.

For the most part, they've
managed to do that,

in that, with the looks,
they are stealing hearts.

Really it's a small motorcycle
that actually looks like a big motorcycle.

It gives the impression of a Japanese sport
motorcycle with two slanted eyes at the front.

It's got things like these air vents
on the side and such,
for the heat generated by the engine,

because as you know these Ninja's
tend to overheat a bit,

maybe not overheat,
that gives the wrong impression,

but it's a motorcycle that needs the cooling
fan on especially in traffic in the city.

They've done things with the
ducts and everything so that

the heat from the fan doesn't
blow onto your legs and feet.

That sounds nice, but it still
seemed a little hot to me,

even though the weather is not that
hot, it's October here in Istanbul.
They've given the tail this special design.

For example, when a passenger
gets on the back,
The foot-pegs are here.

OK, so the passenger is a little
bit 'perched' on the back,

but as for somewhere to hold on to,
it looks like there isn't anywhere,
but they made these on the tail.
The passenger holds on here,

and so you don't have any ugly
handles or knobs showing.
A brilliant little feature.

They came up with a good idea
having the handholds here.

Previously the foot-pegs were rubber,
and they looked quite cheap,

On this new one, they are
completely aluminium

so you can brag that you have
a real sport motorcycle,
they're like foot-pegs on big motorcycles -
these are all very nice features.

The instrument cluster from the old Ninja
used to get a lot of stick,

in fact we used to say it was like
one of those ancient busses.
"Man, what's that!"
On this new one there's a digital display,

there's a big tachometer,
a whole load of information shown,
a fuel gauge etc., these are all very nice.

Normally, for a sport motorcycle
riding position,

they put the seat very high and
the handlebars down low.

There's nothing you can do about it
because that's how it's supposed to be.

It's a sport motorcycle,
the weight is at the front etc,

It's not like that here. It looks like a
sport motorcycle,

but it's a motorcycle for the city,
a beginner motorcycle.

Well now look, the usual riding position
is like this, comfortable, relaxed.
So you don't have to, you know,

"man, my ass is in the air
and my head is down here!"
We aren't stuck in that kind of position.
With this, you're sitting very comfortably.

Oh yeah, we noticed this when filming:
yes, we're sitting comfortably,

it's comfortable to ride, but when you are
sitting and riding comfortably,

it looks terrible in photographs
and videos!

So you have to try and pose,
you have to hold it like this,
and then it will look good.

That is, until you turn the
ignition, and start riding.

Because Kawasaki, as we know,
make nice engines.
With this 300cc engine,
actually 290 or something cc, well anyway,

they say it produces something like 33 hp
at the rear wheel.
That's good, nice, wonderful,

it fits in with the law in Europe for
beginner's licenses too,

as they don't let beginners use
motorcycles with more than 33 hp.
OK, so they are fine there.
It goes well too,
fantastic,
the brakes too are good,

even though they are using
the same discs as on the old Ninja,
they're still good, the brakes.

Maybe they don't exactly make you
clench your teeth, but they're good.
BUT... IF....

you start riding on a road that is a bit
'potholey', a bit wonky,

especially if there are a lot of
corners on that road

and the weight of the motorcycle
needs to shift around a bit,

because you are asking the suspension
both to cope with the potholes,

and on top of that the things you ask it
to do when cornering,

the suspension of the
Ninja 300 isn't up to it.

You can see a nice suspension
system on many motorcycles.
Sometimes stiff, sometimes soft,
but the suspension does the job.

On the Ninja 300, the device that they
call 'suspension' is actually this!
The Ninja 300's suspension.

It feels like they used a
piece of timber instead.

Unfortunately, the Ninja 300's
suspension is terrible.

The front suspension feels a little
softer, especially when braking
it compresses and things, however

still, the rear says to you "Dunk dunk,
let's loosen your kidney stones!"

Unfortunately when entering and
exiting corners, especially when exiting,

when you start to open the throttle
and the back raises up,

it makes it feel even stranger. So
the front is soft, the back is like wood...
that can't be good.

Hello, I'm Doruk Özmen. I've been riding
motorcycles for 2 or 3 years.
I've done around 23,000km.

Actually it's an easy motorcycle to use.
It's easy to change direction.

The response from the handlebars is good,
so that's why I find it easy to use.

Especially the tyres it comes with
from the factory are terrible.

If you buy it, I'd advise you
to definitely change them.

I think the workmanship other than
the mechanics is really bad.

The front fairing starts to
come apart, gaps appears there.

The paintwork beside the headlight
has started to wear off,

despite it only being one year old.
On that point I think it really is poor.

I would recommend it, especially if you
live in a city with a lot of traffic like
Istanbul, Ankara or Izmir.

I think the riding position is not
uncomfortable, not like

an R6 or CBR600RR, you aren't
leaning forward much.
For that, I think it can be recommended.

Then there are the details. Yes,
the paintwork looks very nice.
But if only good paintwork were enough.

The bodywork is separating from the
chassis, you can see the clips here.

People talk about workmanship and
quality of parts, as a general category.

As for workmanship and quality of parts,
the quality of the parts may be good,
but as for workmanship...

For example, when you look inside like this
at some of the connections,
you can see all the wires!

The thermostat plug, the others too,
this side is empty.

If someone gives it a bump,
it would just "chit" break.
It's that cheap.

We didn't like that part of it.
The parts we did like -

it's comfort, it's shape, the street image,
the street cred, that's fantastic.

By quite some distance, among
the beginner motorcycles,

THIS motorcycle is the
most prestigious.

Of course, on a sporty-looking motorcycle,
people aren't expecting much storage,

but here they have done
something interesting.

They have done the typical Kawasaki thing
where we put the key in from below,

here it is, we found it. We put the key in.
The seat comes off,

and we are met by a kind of tray, and
you think there is no room for anything,

but actually it's deceiving because
underneath is the actual storage.

They've made a place that will mostly
protect from water, the rain, the dirt.
Our friend, Doruk, who owns the motorcycle,

has been able to fit a disc lock,
some plastic thing, tools,

implements and other things.
So it has storage space.

Mr. Doruk has fitted some
extras on this motorcycle.

The first and most important is a set
of tyres. Normally, on this motorcycle,

it has those terrible IRC tyres.
Awful, really awful.

Mr. Doruk coughed up the money and
bought Pirelli Rosso 2 tyres.

As a result the motorcycle's grip level has
seriously improved. That's one difference.

A second difference,
an important difference,

is this Akrapovic exhaust
that he had fitted.

It makes a wonderful racket, it was
very loud when I was riding it.

It did have a silencer
but he removed it.

Mr. Doruk doesn't seem to
 like his neighbours at all.

The motor makes an incredible
racket when running.

Kawasaki Turkey have done their usual,
they have given it a ridiculous price-tag.

You know when you go to a hotel,
and you want just a normal soft drink,

but when you buy it from the
lobby in a hotel, it's more expensive.

This motorcycle's price is a bit like that.
It's just a typical beginner motorcycle,

OK, maybe it is 300cc instead of 250cc, but
come on mate, what's that price about?!?

"Well, sir, the tax..."
No, it can't be just because of tax!

When you tot it all up, there's more than
just a high tax on this motorcycle.

Especially when riding in the street, with
the city traffic and everything,

those places where we are going
slow and wonder if we will clip something,
we noticed this when using the mirrors:

on the Ninja 250 the mirrors
were more towards the front,

but now they have moved them back a bit,
and so it lets you see a bit more.

They thought that out well.
But still, for me, for guys my size,

it still shows your elbows a bit,
1/4 of what you see is your elbows.

But the mirrors fold very easily,
they thought about that well.

It closes and opens with a click, it can
be folded the other way too if needed.

They figured that out well. Of course,
it sounds a bit like.... cheap plastic.

In general, when it comes to vibration, it's
acceleration, it's brakes, these are good.

The suspension is wooden, the price-tag
is unfortunately extortionate.

It's a nice beginner motorcycle, but
only IF you can afford it.

That was the Ninja 300.
See you!

title: Kawasaki Ninja 300 - Altın Elbiseli Adam [English Subtitles]
